{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3340559,"name":"Anderson Hall","username":"Xactlysharp","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xactlysharp/{size}/186572_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T13:59:33.293Z","cooked":"

We’ve been having some issues with some drive commands, such as turning the chassis with the l/r triggers, and a “boost mode” button.

These commands work whenever we run them off of SmartDashboard, (the commands only change a variable, so the isFinished field is true for the “boost mode” command).
However, when we try to bind these commands to a button on the driver joystick, the drivetrain maintains it’s current state, i.e. will continue running motors after the button is pressed as if the same inputs are being sent, even when they aren’t.

Meaning, when we press the “boost button” the robot will no longer respond to the default drive command.

When run in Shuffleboard, the command ends instantly (because of the isFinished field being true) and the drivetrain is responsive.

Any ideas on how to make this work with a button?

Also, is there any way to run a command whenever an axis on a controller ≠ 0?

code

I’d suggest that “boost mode” doesn’t need to be a command at all. instead, add a Boolean to your subsystem drive method, and pass the button state in robot container.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T14:22:12.940Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":129,"readers_count":128,"score":65.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340603,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T14:38:42.641Z","cooked":"

There are many ways to handle this, but the most elegant way to do it is to have your default command handle the boost. Really, boosting is a characteristic of your drive command, not your subsystem (unless the drivetrain has a physical boost, like a shifting gearbox.)

If boost is on the subsystem, you need to make sure all of your commands handle it. For example, if you decide to implement any kind of driver assist command that takes over the drivetrain, it will need to make sure boost mode is set properly when it starts and ends, or things won’t work right.

The easiest way to run a command when an axis exceeds a threshold is to use the CommandJoystick class instead of Joystick. It has this capability built in. Another way to do it is with a custom Trigger with a BooleanSupplier that checks the axis value.

Do you have a default command set for the drive subsystem? Should be something like:

drive.setDefaultCommand(driveWithJoysticks)

…this should make sure after any other drive system command finishes, it goes back to this one for your drive.

You can see how we do it here:

…we actually have it set up as default max speed and then we have a “slow mode” button, which is the same as the default command except it scales all the joystick values down.

Hope this helps!

go Churrobots!"},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/4","custom_user_title":"8048 coach - go Churrobots!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340607,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T14:42:34.009Z","cooked":"

@truher This may work in this case, but you essentially have a command that uses the drivetrain subsystem without “requiring” it. That will be problematic if there’s another command running that doesn’t expect this boost, like running a PathPlanner path. It’s best to only have commands that require the subsystem manipulate its state since they don’t know what other command might be in control of the subsystem.

ah, let me clarify: I’m not suggesting that the subsystem have any sort of state that represents boost mode at all. I’m suggesting that the drive method simply scale the driver input based on a Boolean argument. it’s literally just another thing the driver is indicating on the controller, not a state of the system.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T15:05:06.817Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":76,"readers_count":75,"score":55.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44380,"username":"gdefender","name":"Andy Gasser","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340670,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T15:18:37.610Z","cooked":"

Oh I see, that makes sense, I misunderstood. That would be just putting the scaling into the drive method. Then I think our solutions are complementary. I’m suggesting the command handle it, and you’re saying the command could pass a boolean to the drive method to scale the input.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T15:18:37.610Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":76,"readers_count":75,"score":45.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/7","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340674,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T15:21:47.462Z","cooked":"

Alternatively, you could schedule a different drive command which scales the inputs differently. This would let you parameterize the drive command with immutable/constant scaling parameters instead of a supplier.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T15:22:34.500Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":71,"readers_count":70,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340768,"name":"Anderson Hall","username":"Xactlysharp","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xactlysharp/{size}/186572_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T16:55:47.528Z","cooked":"

I’ve tried creating a boolean inside of the drive subsystem, but actually changing the speed in the drive command hasn’t worked.

We have a default drive command setup, but the robot still likes to not respond to changes in joysticks whenever we run a command that somehow effects the drive command/subsystem

We did try this:

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T17:16:57.276Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":51,"readers_count":50,"score":15.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"Anderson Hall","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/f/7/f73db30487a4101c561c2ab417d1f45d5958f349.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44380,"username":"gdefender","name":"Andy Gasser","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55065,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8088 Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/12","custom_user_title":"8088 Alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340802,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T17:20:27.822Z","cooked":"

the reason that’s happening is that you’re using a command that only does some of the driving work. the choices here are:

  1. use two commands. one for default speed, one for boost mode. they’re almost exactly the same except for the speed multiplier. both “require” the subsystem, so when you schedule the boost, it cancels the default, and when the boost ends, the default starts again.
  2. use one default command, which handles boosting.

all these commands would need to call “subsystem.drive” in “command.execute.”

what’s happening now is that your default command is calling “drive” but your “boost” command does not, so the subsystem just keeps obeying the most-recent “drive” call.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T17:20:27.822Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":45.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":55065,"username":"Xactlysharp","name":"Anderson Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xactlysharp/{size}/186572_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340803,"name":"Anderson Hall","username":"Xactlysharp","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xactlysharp/{size}/186572_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T17:22:08.189Z","cooked":"

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T17:22:08.189Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"Anderson Hall","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55065,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8088 Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/14","custom_user_title":"8088 Alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340812,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T17:34:43.186Z","cooked":"

the command scheduler will take care of running the default command.

i think if you want to keep the idea where the “boost” command simply changes the subsystem state, then you should use “trigger.ontrue” instead of “whiletrue” and your SetDriveRatio command should do all the work in initialize().

that way the scheduler will run the boost command for one cycle and then go back to the default command 0.02 sec later.

no, the “initialize” method is called each time the command is scheduled, i.e. each time the button is pressed.

That is what I mean by axis, but your usage looks a little off. I pulled down your code, and I see you are using XBox controllers, not joysticks. In that case, I recommend you use CommandXboxController. You should also only create one instance of XBoxController or CommandXboxController per device (port), so create it once and reuse it.

  1. Change the type of your your driver and/or operator controllers to CommandXboxController
// The driver's controller
CommandXboxController m_driverController = new CommandXboxController(OIConstants.kDriverControllerPort);
// The operator's controller
CommandXboxController m_operatorController = new CommandXboxController(OIConstants.kOperatorControllerPort);
  1. Instead of needing to create JoystickButton objects and binding buttons by ID, you can use trigger methods with meaningful names:
final Trigger AutoAim = m_driverController.a();
AutoAim.toggleOnTrue(new AutoAim(m_shooter, m_pivot, m_drivesubsystem));

final Trigger PivotUp = m_driverController.b();
PivotUp.whileTrue(new AngleSub(m_pivot));

final Trigger SetX = m_driverController.x(); 
SetX.whileTrue(new xPattern(m_drivesubsystem));

... and so on
  1. Finally, what you were actually asking about. CommandXboxController has a couple helpful methods for creating a trigger based on an axis. You can use axisGreaterThan with an axis number (I prefer using the constants from XBoxController.Axis instead of magic numbers), or you can use the methods like rightTrigger():
Trigger leftTrigger = m_driverController.axisGreaterThan(Axis.kLeftTrigger.value, .02);
Trigger rightTrigger = m_driverController.rightTrigger(.02);
","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T18:57:50.808Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":43,"readers_count":42,"score":23.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459691,"topic_slug":"running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55065,"username":"Xactlysharp","name":"Anderson Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xactlysharp/{size}/186572_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/running-commands-in-drive-subsystem-stops-the-default-drive-command/459691/19","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3340870,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T18:55:25.832Z","cooked":"

I will try to give you one option here that’s fully fleshed out. There are lots of different options, and I think you’re getting lost. The core of the problem is that only one command can use a subsystem at a time.

The simplest option is to have a single command that handles both regular speed and boost mode.

  1. Delete SetDriveRatio command.
  2. Delete DriveSubsystem.setSpeedRatio().
  3. Make kMaxSpeedMetersPerSecond final so it it truly a constant that represents the drivetrain’s top speed.
  4. Finally, update your default command to handle the button press and increase/decrease the max speed. Since you have the command inline, it could look like this (don’t forget the addition of curly braces):
m_drivesubsystem.setDefaultCommand(
    // The left stick controls translation of the robot.
    // Turning is controlled by the X axis of the right stick.
    new RunCommand(
        () -> {
          // Go full speed is "boost mode", go .75 speed in normal mode
          var boostRatio = m_driverController.getHID().getYButton() ? 1 : .75;
          m_drivesubsystem.drive(
              -MathUtil.applyDeadband(m_driverController.getLeftY(), OIConstants.kDriveDeadband) * boostRatio,
              -MathUtil.applyDeadband(m_driverController.getLeftX(), OIConstants.kDriveDeadband) * boostRatio,
              -MathUtil.applyDeadband(m_driverController.getRightX(), OIConstants.kDriveDeadband),
              true, true); // drivescheme sets either field centric or not
        },
        m_drivesubsystem));
